item.title: Fixed: Obelisk not working in Ableton Live
item.description:
So when using the Frozen Plains Obelisk plugin in Ableton live 10 (I‚Äôm running10.1.15) following Frozen Plains instructions doesn‚Äôt work.
If you change the 2nd drop down on the synth/instrument track to Obelisk64 instead of Pre FX then it will work.

Additionally, if you don‚Äôt want record a whole extra midi track for the Obelisk track then instead of arming both track, just set to Obelisk track to In on the monitoring and then arm the instrument you want to record. This has the added benefit of being able to easily have multiple instruments using Obelisk and switch to record on whichever one you want to play

item.title: SOLVED: Spotify desktop client communication failed
item.description:
If you receive the message¬†Spotify desktop client communication failed when trying to¬†Login with Facebook to the Spotify app here‚Äôs why and how to fix it.

Reason

It was because I have 2 factor security turned on.

Resolution

  1. Go to https://www.facebook.com/settings?tab=security&view
  2. On the line App Passwords click Edit
  3. Click the Generate App Passwords link
  4. Click the¬†Generate App Passwords¬†button
  5. Enter a friendly name for what this is for i.e. Spotify
  6. Click¬†Generate Password
  7. Copy the password in the¬†normal¬†spotify logon password box.
  8. enter your FB email address as the username.
  9. HEY PRESTO!

item.title: Lyrical Challenges ‚Äì Tips To Write Song Lyrics
item.description:
A friend asked me to write a piece on setting lyrical challenges for myself so I thought I‚Äôd post it here as well.

The Goal is to Have a Goal

First things first. When setting a lyric challenge having a goal is the key. If you‚Äôve got no reason to write a song you won‚Äôt get a word written down.
Often the reason is heartbreak or sitting there bored with your guitar in hand and happening upon something to explore. Setting a goal with a song challenge is a more proactive way of writing songs.

Once you have a goal you have something to work towards, whether it‚Äôs write one song by the end of the day, or write a song a day.

A Creative Goal

The next thing is to have a goal that inspires some interesting creative angles. It‚Äôs very easy to become stale in musical style and lyrical theme, something to put your outside your comfort zone, but also something to make you take different approaches to those you‚Äôd would normally take.

For instance, a title for a song normally doesn‚Äôt come to mind till you‚Äôve written a song. Start with a handful of titles, pick one and and explore what it could mean.
‚ÄúSee you on the¬†other side¬†of goodbye‚Äù ‚Äì Could be about the end of a relationship, or it could be about what happens after a relationship has ended and lovers want to remain friends. Or it could be about someone dying and the morning process.

Your Starter For 10

Ok so there‚Äôs a few suggestions for lyrical challenges to get your started

  • Title Ideas¬†http://www.lyricideas.com/¬†‚Äì Lists 10 potential song titles (and lyrics) per day
  • Write a Reply ‚Äì Find a favourite song and write a reply song
  • A novel idea ‚Äì Try and capture the main theme of a favourite character in a novel in a song
  • 5 Minute Rush ‚Äì A great way to quiet¬†your inner critic set a timer and write as much of a song as you can in 5 minutes.
  • Change Position ‚Äì If you‚Äôre songs are normally written in the first person, or normally from a narrator‚Äôs point of view then switch it up. Force yourself to use another perspective.
  • One a Day ‚Äì Similar to some bloggers, taking a 30 day challenge of a song. Write one song a day for 30 days. It doesn‚Äôt have to be a good song. But the act of writing every day will encourage your brain to generate more lyrics all the time and doing anything for 30 days in a row is a great way of starting to form a habit.

Take Advantage Of Your Little Thoughts

Whilst this doesn‚Äôt quite fit in as a challenge, I implore every lyricist to buy some of these soft pocket notebooks¬†and carrying one of these very pocketable pens¬†and take them absolutely everywhere with you! The times when I‚Äôve written the most lyrics are the times when I‚Äôm most idea and my brain has time to wander.

I might have a few minutes on a bus or a tube and my mind idly wanders through one thought or another, maybe driven by what I see in front of me, or maybe I‚Äôm lost in my own mind. But then BAM! I‚Äôm hit but a beautiful turn of phrase or way of perceiving something that I‚Äôd not thought of before.
If I can capture that right there and then I have a chance of working it into a song.
Otherwise it‚Äôs gone forever!

I‚Äôve tried to mimic this spontaneous note taking using my ever-present smart phone instead. However there‚Äôs something so unforgiving about typing text into a phone that means I lose the meaning almost as much as if I‚Äôd never written it down at all.

Good luck with your lyric writing!

item.title: SOPA and PIPA Alternatives
item.description:
SOPA and PIPA seek to prevent and punish piracy thru law and technical obstruction. Piracy, is wrong, most of us have pirated something in our time, even if it was copying a friends cassette or cd so you could have a copy of an album your mate owns, in our hearts we all know we‚Äôre being a little bit naughty when we do it.

Here‚Äôs the thing, the music and film industry don‚Äôt care too much if you are recording a film off TV at home that they own the rights too, or record a copy of a song off the radio. It‚Äôs small scale, it‚Äôs not really affecting their bottom line.
They care when it starts to make their fat wallets thinner and makes them look inaffective at protecting their intellectual properly.

However the gist of it is that as long as the amount of legal plays/buys of a song/movie Vs the amount of pirated copies of a song or movie is in their favour and keeps their wallets fat they won‚Äôt really give a rats arse.

So why not embrace the new digital landscape, why not make music and movies so easy to get and reasonably priced that piracy seems like idiocy?
Since buying a Spotify premium account subscription I‚Äôve been lovingly listening to more new albums than I ever did before. I‚Äôve been able to share these tracks via Spotify to friends and colleagues, and instead of a radio playing in the office now we have Spotify playing with a collaborative playlist that we all add tracks to. We have our own, very eclectic, radio station thru Spotify and it‚Äôs exposing colleagues to new tracks continually.

With the recent launch of Netflix in the UK, I‚Äôve watched films and tv series, old and new, much of which is shared on my Facebook timeline and I‚Äôve recommended films, and Netflix to friends.

So why is the film and music industry trying to make it so hard for me to get a hold of the product that they want me to have. Just make it easy and cheap enough and we‚Äôll take the deal.

The downside to this streaming, legitimate consumption of movies and music is that some labels and/or artists choose not to release their product this way, and some major labels release their latest products.
I look forward to watching Netflix deal grow in the UK so their provision grows, and I look forward to being able to get hold of the latest albums immediately on Spotify.
Why record, movie companies and artists feel the need to be so prohibitive and restrictive in this I don‚Äôt know. They seem to be scared of technology.

The message is simple, make the gatorade taste nice and we‚Äôll gladly gulp it down.
